title: ICEs and transmutes in safe Rust with associated_type_defaults and generic_associated_types

labels.name: I-ICE
labels.description: Issue: The compiler panicked, giving an Internal Compilation Error (ICE) ❄️

labels.name: E-needs-test
labels.description: Call for participation: writing correctness tests

labels.name: A-associated-items
labels.description: Area: Associated items such as associated types and consts.

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: I-unsound
labels.description: Issue: A soundness hole (worst kind of bug), see: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soundness

labels.name: requires-nightly
labels.description: This issue requires a nightly compiler in some way.

body:
```rust
#![feature(associated_type_defaults)]
#![feature(generic_associated_types)]
#![allow(incomplete_features)]

trait Trait1 {
    fn foo();
}

trait Trait2 {
    type Associated: Trait1 = Self;
}

impl Trait2 for () {}

fn call_foo<T: Trait2>() {
    T::Associated::foo()
}

fn main() {
    call_foo::<()>()
}
```

([Playground](https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=nightly&mode=debug&edition=2018&gist=cb7d183aad977accdd4433c908db197a))

Errors:

Removing the `generic_associated_types` makes this generate appropriate error messages. Seems like combining `associated_type_defaults` and `generic_associated_types` is rather uncommon, at least there are no other issues with both labels yet.
